<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 688, 529]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 564, 168, 580]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 596, 320, 613]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 648, 250, 665]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 680, 151, 696]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 721, 339, 739]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 759, 207, 775]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 790, 228, 807]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 826, 238, 843]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel

\[g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{-2}\]

\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 160, 625, 180]]<|/det|>
\[e = 1.60\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 191, 630, 211]]<|/det|>
\[1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 222, 630, 243]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 252, 630, 273]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 284, 648, 305]]<|/det|>
\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 315, 630, 335]]<|/det|>
\[R = 8.31\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 345, 648, 365]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 375, 688, 396]]<|/det|>
\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{N m}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 406, 650, 462]]<|/det|>
\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\] \[\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 472, 635, 492]]<|/det|>
\[h = 6.63\times 10^{-34}\mathrm{Js}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 503, 685, 523]]<|/det|>
\[\sigma = 5.67\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{Wm}^{-2}\mathrm{K}^{-4}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 592, 580, 631]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 648, 549, 667]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 677, 541, 696]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 707, 555, 744]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{s}}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{\mathrm{s}}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 756, 551, 775]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 787, 606, 807]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 816, 613, 851]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 781, 89]]<|/det|>
A solid metal sphere has a diameter of \((3.42 \pm 0.02) \text{cm}\) and a mass of \((67 \pm 2) \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 102, 524, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density, in \(\text{g} \text{cm}^{- 3}\), of the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 303, 897, 322]]<|/det|>
<form>density = ............................................. $\text{g} \text{cm}^{- 3}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[868, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 148, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 589, 353]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in the density.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 581, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
An archer releases an arrow towards a target at a velocity of \(65.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(4.30^{\circ}\) above the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 114, 902, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 355, 591, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
When released, the tip of the arrow is a horizontal distance of \(70.0 \text{m}\) from the target and \(1.66 \text{m}\) above the horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 432, 435, 450]]<|/det|>
The arrow hits the centre of the target.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 463, 813, 482]]<|/det|>
Assume that air resistance is negligible and that all the mass of the arrow is at its tip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 146, 513]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 705, 512]]<|/det|>
Show that the time taken for the arrow to reach the target is 1.08 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 603, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 634, 146, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 690, 653]]<|/det|>
Calculate the height of the centre of the target above the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 826, 920, 844]]<|/det|>
<form>height above ground = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
By considering energy changes, state and explain how the final kinetic energy of the arrow as it hits the target compares with its initial kinetic energy immediately after release. A numerical calculation is not required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 245, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 284, 90]]<|/det|>
Define velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A constant driving force of \(2400\mathrm{N}\) acts on a car of mass \(1200\mathrm{kg}\). The car accelerates from rest in a straight line along a horizontal road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 209, 685, 228]]<|/det|>
Assume that the resistive forces acting on the car are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 181, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 499, 260]]<|/det|>
Calculate the acceleration of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 317, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = ............................................ $\text{ms}^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 317, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 181, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 350, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, sketch a graph showing the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the car for the first 20 seconds of its motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 396, 331, 414]]<|/det|>
Label this line A.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 425, 803, 812]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 829, 532, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>Fig. 3.1</mark>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 842, 920, 861]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
In reality, a resistive force due to air resistance acts on the car in **(b)**. This resistive force increases with speed until it becomes equal in magnitude to the driving force at time \(t = 12 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 918, 150]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, sketch a second line to show the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the car for the first 20 seconds of its motion. Label this line B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 134, 917, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 164, 181, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 918, 197]]<|/det|>
At time \(t = 20 \text{s}\), the driving force is increased to \(3000 \text{N}\) and remains constant at this value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 893, 228]]<|/det|>
Describe how the velocity of the car changes due to this increase in the driving force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 367, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A mass \(m\) moves a vertical distance \(\Delta h\) in a uniform gravitational field and gains gravitational potential energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\). The acceleration of free fall is \(g\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 512, 135]]<|/det|>
Use the concept of work done to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 149, 554, 168]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}} = mg\Delta h.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 335, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 146, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
A \(0.60\mathrm{kg}\) mass is attached to a string which is wrapped around the wheel of a generator, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 408, 809, 644]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 658, 532, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 689, 920, 737]]<|/det|>
The mass is held stationary above the floor. When released, the mass initially accelerates and then falls at a steady speed and spins the wheel. The generator causes a current in a resistor. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 751, 764, 769]]<|/det|>
State the main energy change when the mass is falling at a steady speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 782, 757, 800]]<|/det|>
............................................ energy to ............................................ energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 782, 920, 800]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
When falling at a steady speed, the mass in **(b)** falls through a vertical distance of \(1.4 \text{m}\) in a time of \(4.0 \text{s}\). This causes a current of \(90 \text{mA}\) in the resistor. The resistance of the resistor is \(47 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 243, 151]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 180, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 532, 183]]<|/det|>
the rate of work done by the falling mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<form>rate of work done = .................................................... W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 335, 181, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 335, 485, 353]]<|/det|>
the power dissipated in the resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 473, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>power = .................................................... W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 504, 180, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 447, 523]]<|/det|>
the efficiency of the generator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 643, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<form>efficiency = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 674, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Parallel light rays from the Sun are incident normally on a magnifying glass. The magnifying glass directs the light to an area A of radius \(r\), as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 163, 253, 196]]<|/det|>
parallel light rays from Sun

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 109, 893, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 338, 591, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
The magnifying glass is circular in cross-section with a radius of \(5.5 \text{cm}\). The intensity of the light from the Sun incident on the magnifying glass is \(1.3 \text{kW} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 415, 850, 435]]<|/det|>
Assume that all of the light incident on the magnifying glass is transmitted through it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 181, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 838, 467]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power of the light from the Sun incident on the magnifying glass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 574, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
<form>power = .................................................... $W$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 605, 181, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 605, 400, 624]]<|/det|>
The value of \(r\) is \(1.5 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 561, 655]]<|/det|>
Calculate the intensity of the light on area A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 777, 920, 796]]<|/det|>
<form>intensity = .................................................... $\text{W} \text{m}^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 777, 920, 796]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 876, 89]]<|/det|>
A laser emits a beam of electromagnetic waves of frequency \(3.7 \times 10^{15} \text{Hz}\) in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 181, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 648, 120]]<|/det|>
Show that the wavelength of the waves is \(8.1 \times 10^{- 8} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 242, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 273, 845, 291]]<|/det|>
State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum to which these waves belong.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 335, 181, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
The beam from the laser now passes through a diffraction grating with 2400 lines per millimetre. A detector sensitive to the waves emitted by the laser is moved through an arc of \(180^{\circ}\) in order to detect the maxima produced by the waves passing through the grating, as shown in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 403, 845, 686]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 696, 534, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Calculate the number of maxima detected as the detector moves through \(180^{\circ}\) along the line shown in Fig. 5.2. Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 319, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>number of maxima detected = .................................................... [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 351, 180, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
The laser is now replaced with one that emits electromagnetic waves with a wavelength of \(300 \text{nm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
Explain, without calculation, what happens to the number of maxima now detected. Assume that the detector is also sensitive to this wavelength of electromagnetic waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 533, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]
